Award.AwardTitle: IRES: Informal Science Learning in Ecological Contexts: Science Learning and Native Language Use in Contrasting North American and Mongolian Mountain Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical part.
This is a collaborative research project between Montana State University (MSU), Bozeman, USA and Gorno-Altaisk State University (GASU), Altai Republic, Russian Federation. In this NSF International Research Experiences for Students project MSU students will travel to the Altai Republic and work with faculty and students at Gorno-Altaisk University to conduct research related to native language use in learning ecological sciences in informal settings. Student researchers will conduct individual studies related to the project theme of science learning in ecological contexts. This project will help students learn how to conduct educational research related to the ecological learning experiences of indigenous youth (ages12-16) and the use and influence of native language in learning about environment. This research directly addresses the results of our prior NSF supported work that identified shared issues of indigenous people, natural resources and the decline of native language use among underserved populations in the Altai and Yellowstone systems. This project contributes significantly to our emerging understanding of science learning in informal settings. It addresses a unique conception of ecological learning in three dimensions; personal, community and cultural perspectives. Research and education objectives align with modern conceptualizations of informal science learning as proposed by the National Academies of Science (2009). The MSU-GASU collaboration provides a holistic view of science learning and will unite diverse intellectual resources and research efforts in unique ecological and social systems. Both the Yellowstone and Altai mountain systems are of global concern as part of worldwide natural and cultural resources impacted by pervasive development, recreation and tourism activities and climate change. The underlying theoretical foundation for learning proposed in this research project is the basis for effective approaches to enable isolated rural populations to contribute traditional knowledge and wisdom to contemporary issues related to world-wide ecological and cultural issues including global climate change. Aspects of sustainability practices that are embedded in the knowledge and social processes of both marginalized and dominant societies will be better understood and taken into consideration for future research and education activities. Research outcomes will contribute to more effective informal, place-based and experiential science learning to help empower communities and decision makers in meeting challenges of sustainability. Inevitably, we expect this work to extend our understanding of science learning related to critical natural and cultural resources and their management. An understanding of how, why and where learning takes place will help extend the US and international research and education agendas related to informal science learning, natural and cultural resource management and sustainability.

Non-technical part.
This is a collaborative research project between Montana State University (MSU), Bozeman, USA and Gorno-Altaisk State University (GASU), Altai Republic, Russian Federation. In this NSF International Research Experiences for Students project MSU students will travel to the Altai Republic and work with faculty and students at Gorno-Altaisk University to conduct research related to native language use in learning ecological sciences in informal settings. Student researchers will conduct individual studies related to the project theme of science learning in ecological contexts. This project we will help students learn how to conduct educational research related to the ecological learning experiences of indigenous youth (ages12-16) and the use and influence of native language in learning about environment. Three cohorts of five MSU students will travel to the Altai Republic for eight weeks in the summers of 2013, 2014 & 2015. MSU students will comprise a research team with GASU science, education and language faculty to conduct research in the city of Gorno-Altaisk, two medium size villages such as Onguday and two small villages such as Karakol. We expect to work with youth in each setting and interview a representative sample at each site. As a research team we expect to gain a better understanding of how indigenous youth use native Altai language in informal settings to learn about environment. We expect to compare sights within the study. As part of our larger research interests in ecological learning and native people, we will conduct a similar comparative study in the Yellowstone Ecosystem with Native American youth. The studies associated with this project will add to our understanding about the extent and nature of native language use to learn science in underserved populations in very sensitive and unique ecological and cultural settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funded in 2013, the primary goal of the project is to engage Indigenous (Native American) students from the Yellowstone Mountain System (broadly construed) in learning interdisciplinary research methodologies, diverse data acquisition methods, and complex cross-cultural communication skills, while developing positive attitudes and values towards collaborative international engagement in STEM research and related activities. The project focuses on several issues that align it with MSU’s strategic plan, particularly in the areas of Learning, Engagement, Integration, and Access. Students recruited to what is informally known as the "Yellowstone Altai Sayan Project" (YASP) compare and contrast diverse efforts to promote environmental sustainability across similar threatened ecosystems and bioregions, work to better understand the role of Indigenous languages and worldviews in the preservation of traditional ecological knowledges, and integrate innovative, participatory research methodologies with educational activities.

In Russia, students joined native peers from a regional university for home stays in their Altaian villages. Student feedback praised the personal gain of welcoming homestays and the role of story sharing when accompanied by deep listening. In Mongolia, students interacted with indigenous elders and their families in the sharing of factual and cultural information on medicinal plants, the role and importance of indigenous hunting privileges in increasingly controlled environments, the practice of shamanism, similarities and differences in indigenous calendars as influenced by geographic location and environmental (climate?) change, the sacredness of geographic features and places, and the developing role of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and Global Positioning Systems (GPS). In most instances Asian and North American participants discovered more commonalities than differences. 

Participation in the 2016 and 2017 American Indigenous Research Association meetings exposed students and faculty to a broad sphere of indigenous research conducted through emerging principles of Indigenous Research Methodologies. Students presented their projects at both meetings and received valuable support and feedback from colleagues, community workers and professors from Indigenous communities around the globe.

Intellectual Merit

Native American and indigenous Asian learners are conditioned by their ‘place’ and their culture. Success in STEM-related learning and application is enhanced when the learner can see the role of new knowledge within a familiar cultural context such as actually using spatial science tools of Global Positioning Systems (GPS) and Geographic Information Systems (GIS) to identify and map culturally important sacred sites, wildlife habitat, or herder migration routes, campsites, and pastures. Likewise, comparisons of native seasonal calendars bring opportunities to realize ecological impacts of climate change on key weather patterns or species key to indigenous lifestyles. Learning to identify and use medicinal plants provides opportunities to understand botanical keys, plant taxonomy, and human physiology within cultural and environmental contexts. In these cross-cultural experiences, the role of accurate language to describe, measure, and evaluate was highlighted as a key to understanding quantitative aspects of place-based processes occurring within one’s home landscape such as changes in date of first or last frost, intensity of precipitation events, levels of flooding, populations and seasonal distribution of game animals, or numbers of active shaman.

Broader Impacts

For people interested in promoting STEM learning, it is first important to acknowledge the cultural gap between indigenous learning coming from direct experience with place and culture and the sometimes more abstract Western approach which starts with a minimum number of variables. Native learners want to understand the relevance of STEM learning and are therefore more interested and motivated when they understand or become aware of the usefulness of STEM based tools and approaches such as the spatial science tools of GIS and GPS. Learner commitment is also critical to STEM learning. Broadening one’s experiential base and viewpoint by experiencing a different but similar landscape and culture, and then engaging in peer to peer comparisons, helped participants more clearly understand their own realities and the relevance of STEM-based tools. These processes also serve to validate the importance of one’s own place and culture as key foundation blocks upon which to build STEM knowledge and skills, much as an artist builds technical skills to support cultural viewpoints. And finally, this project has greatly increased awareness of participating teaching faculty and administrators of the professional status of ‘indigenous science’ and the emerging ground rules for research involving indigenous communities.

A synthesis of findings suggests similar views within the Russian Altai, the Mongolian Sayan (Darhad Valley) and Yellowstone ecosystems regarding Indigenous research methodologies and holistic approaches, especially as related to the importance of Indigenous language for specialized local environmental understanding; recognition of climate change, resource development, and tourism impacts on environment and culture; and awareness of story and experience as culturally and scientifically valid means of transmitting knowledge.
